Sometimes when I couldn't find any I would watch the Growing Souls Gospel Hour, where they would tell Bible stories for children and sing hymns. One
en_second_half: of the women was called Serena Joy. She was the lead soprano. She was ash blond, petite, with a snub nose and huge blue eyes which she'd turn upwards during hymns. She could smile and cry at the same time, one tear or two sliding gracefully down her cheek, as if on cue, as her voice lifted through its highest notes, tremulous, effortless. It was after that she went on to other things.
en_results_raw: of the preachers, a tall, thin man with a kind face, began to tell the story of the Prodigal Son. I was captivated by the way he spoke, his voice rising and falling in a soothing cadence that made me feel like I was right there with the son, wandering through the desert, feeling lost and alone. As he spoke, the camera panned across the studio audience, showing children sitting with their parents, all of them looking rapt and attentive. I felt like I was a part of it, like I was sitting right there with them, feeling the same sense of wonder and awe. When the preacher finished the story, the camera cut to a shot of the entire studio, and I saw the preacher's wife, a woman with a warm smile and a kind face, standing at the piano, playing a soft melody that seemed to match the rhythm of my heartbeat. I felt a sense of peace wash over me, a sense of belonging that I had never felt before. From that moment on, I was hooked on the Growing Souls Gospel Hour, watching it every Sunday morning, feeling like I was a part of something bigger than myself. As I grew older, I began to realize that the sense of peace and belonging I felt during those Sunday morning broadcasts was something that I couldn't find anywhere else, and it was something that I desperately needed. I began to crave it, to seek it out in other places, but it was never quite the same. There was something about the combination of the preacher's soothing voice, the studio audience, and the preacher's wife's piano playing that created a sense of magic that I couldn't find anywhere else. Even now, as an adult, I still find myself thinking back to those Sunday morning broadcasts, feeling a sense of nostalgia wash over me as I remember the sense of peace and belonging that I felt during those early morning hours. It's a feeling that I've been chasing ever since, a feeling that I've never quite been able to recapture, but it's a feeling that I'll always treasure, a reminder of the power of television to transport us to another time and place, to make us feel like we're a part of something bigger than ourselves.
